course.subject: CENG
course.name: Chemical and Biological Reaction Engineering
course.description: Stoichiometry and reaction equilibria. Homogeneous reactions kinetics. Mole balances: batch, continuous-stirred tank and plug flow reactors. Collection and analysis of rate data. Catalytic and enzymatic reaction kinetics and reactor design. Diffusion effects. Examples from chemical and biological processes.
course.prerequisites: CHEM 1010 OR CHEM 1020

reviews.author: anonymous_j
reviews.title: Chemical and Biological Reaction Engineering
reviews.comment_content:
Week 1  Introduction, Reactions and Reactors
Week 2  Conversion and Reactor Sizing
Week 3-4   Rate Laws and Stoichiometry
Week 5 Collection and Analysis of Data
Week 6  Midterm Examination
Week 6-7   Isothermal Reactor Design -1
Week 8  Isothermal Reactor Design -2
Week 9   Introduction to New Reactor Systems
Week 10-11 Bioreactions and Bioreactors
Week 12-13 Catalysis and Catalytic Reactors
Week 14  Review
Week 15 Final Examination

The content is pretty decent and well-structured. The transition between lectures and lectures is smooth and as long as you understand the concept, you will master it quite soon. It requires calculation and basically, it will be easier if you have fundamental chemistry knowledge. It will help a lot if you always refer to the textbook and finish all end-chapter questions.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof is good at teaching. He explains all concepts and calculation procedures comprehensively. He will also share his past experience in reaction engineering during the lecture. However, asking any questions during class is better than sending emails.
reviews.comment_grading:
All marks for homework won't be released. The final exam result was not released as well.

Midterm: 93 (Mean: 76)
Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: There are 5 assignments in total and all were due 2-3 weeks after release. Class participation will be graded by answering some questions and performing calculations during class. You will get the marks for class participation if you attend the lecture and submit your worksheet for the calculations.

Have video to see.
But time is limit no enough time to teach but he want to teach more
reviews.comment_grading:
The course is graded on 3 thing:

10% Homework (5 pieces, you have to do one every 2-3 weeks on average)
45% Quizzes (4 quizzes in total, but only the best 3 counted)
45% Finals
reviews.comment_workload: not much workload but ma fa

reviews.author: Eclipse
reviews.comment_content:
The course covers 9 topics within the realm of reaction and reactor engineering, the first 4 being the basics and the next 5 being applications of the basic knowledge and principles on specific situation. The basic topics are:

1. Mole Balance
2. Conversion and Reactor Sizing
3. Rate Laws and Stoichiometry
4. Rate Analysis

The applied topics are:

5. Isothermal Reactors
6. Multiple Reactions
7. Non-isothermal reactors
8. Bio-reactions and Bioreactors
9. Catalysis and Catalytic Reactors

Overall, the course is manageable if you do pay diligent attention in class and ask Marshal anything that you do not understand. However, if you are planning on skipping classes or just relying on the lecture notes because the quizzes and finals are open book, you might wanna think twice, because the content can be pretty hard to swallow on your own.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Marshal teaches pretty well, and tries his best to make things more fun and understandable for his students. He loves to answer questions (just shoot him an email, he will reply in almost an instant), and also ensures that the students are learning by asking students the contents of the previous lectures.

Also, if you do well for your quiz, you get a $50 coupon for Park'n'shop, which adds extra points to his teaching :P
reviews.comment_grading:
The course is graded on 3 materials:

10% Homework (5 pieces, you have to do one every 2-3 weeks on average)
45% Quizzes (4 quizzes in total, but only the best 3 counted)
45% Finals

While the mean and SD for the quizzes are not known, the statistics for the finals are as following:

Mean: 44/100
SD: 15

Meanwhile, the grading is good. Nothing much more to say.
The class is usually small (less than 70 people usually) so Marshal seems to mix curving and absolute grading. For my semester it was:

Anyone 70 and above - A+
65 and above - A
60 and above - A-
So on and so forth, with the mean at about B.
reviews.comment_workload: The 5 pieces of homework and 4 quizzes seems a tad heavy so I gave a B. Otherwise, since the quizzes and finals are open book, the workload of studying for the course is not very heavy, though one might have to spend some time on understanding the concepts than to memorize everything.

reviews.author: Bohr
reviews.title: Reactor Engineering Good Course!!!
reviews.comment_content:
Eight topics:
1. Introduction
2. Conversion and sizing problem
3. Rate Laws and Stoichiometry
4. Collection and Analysis of Data
5. Isothermal Reactor Design
6. Multiple Reactions
7. Bioreactions and Bioreactors
8. Catalysis and Catalytic Reactors
reviews.comment_teaching:
Marshal is very nice and willing to answer the students' questions
He explains the teaching content clearly and encourages students to deepen our understanding for the topics taught in the course
reviews.comment_grading:
45% Quiz (choose 3 best quiz, total 4 quiz) [Open book]
10% HW (total: 5)
45% Final [Open book]

The quizzes are very interesting (even through I did not perform well in quizzes) and Marshal changes most of questions for the quizzes every year.

The final exam in this year is interesting.

Good Grade!!!!!
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload
5 HW (they are easy and the last hw includes Aspen stimulation)
[Need to use MATLAB and polymath in HW]

reviews.author: ddd
reviews.comment_content:
1. Introduction and mole balance
2. Conversion and reactor sizing
3. Rate law and stoichiometry
4. Analysis of rate
5. Isothermal reactor
6. Multiple reactions
7. Bioreaction and bioreactors
8. Catalyst and catalysis reactor
reviews.comment_teaching: Maybe the class is not very interesting, but Marshal is a good professor. Some people may have problems with understanding his accent. Nevertheless, he has the knowledge and if you approach him, he will explain everything to you.
reviews.comment_grading:
homeworks: 5*1% = 5%
in-class quizzes (best 3 out of 4): 3*15% = 45%
final exam: 50%

the quizzes are easier than final, so it's better if you get good scores for them

without any special commitment got B range, if you work a little bit, A range shouldn't be a problem
reviews.comment_workload: You need to be prepared for the quizzes. Also, you need some time to work on homeworks. Except for that and the final, there is not much to do.
